One of the funniest (and most popular) movies of all time, an outrageously silly (and bloody) story of the Python troupe's search for the Holy Grail. One classic scene after another, exceptional job all around; stunning photography by Terry Bedford, memorable theme music by Neil Innes.

When it comes to comedies, they tend to be hit-or-miss movies. The sense of humor that goes into comedies reaches some audiences while others find it distasteful. That being said, it can be safely said that Monty Python and the Holy Grail is a comedy for virtually everyone. It is even a good experience for children since there is really only one suggestive scene and it is very brief.

Nearly every scene in this film is comic gold and very quotable. Who can forget the black night remarking "'tis but a flesh wound," the holy hand grenade, or even the opening scene (are you suggesting coconuts migrate)? Even great historical allusions are made for humor, such as a reference to the idea of the Trojan horse.

The film also has a great sense of self-awareness and is very meta. The narrator comments on the animator at one point, a woman dressed in white refers to the script of the film, and the characters refer to specific scenes from earlier in the film. This is all in good fun and its self-awareness is primarily meant to add to the humor rather than commenting on art in general which more "serious" meta texts tend to do.

However, this is a strange film when you take into account that from time to time in the film historians appear to briefly comment on the time period and are disregarded the next second as well as other people that are clearly not from the medieval time period becoming involved in the film. This aspect causes the film to end very strangely and abruptly. Monty Python and the Holy Grail would be stronger if it had a more definitive conclusion than the one it does.

Filled with comedic gold, Monty Python and the Holy Grail is a very enjoyable experience.

Monty Python and the Holy Grail is one of those rare comedies whose influence on the genre has been huge, yet there has never been another film quite like it. The film is simply the definition of great comedy: all Python members are at the top of their games, the running time of 90 minutes makes it extremely sharp and efficient, and it richly uses various forms of comedy, from surreal absurdity to slapstick and from satire to running gags. The laughs are endless and unstoppable, from the uproarious opening credits to the abrupt and incredibly silly ending. The poor production values and cheap look only make the film funnier; it is widely known the budget was so low the actors couldn't ride real horses, and the ending was supposed to be entirely different, but there was not enough time and money to execute it. Along with The Big Lebowski, The Holy Grail is the all-time comedy classic, one of the greatest films of all time, and a film that is always equally funny, whether you're watching it drunk, sober, alone or in company.

This is, at least vaguely, the story of Arthur, King of the Britons (Graham Chapman).  He is gathering knights to join him at his castle at Camelot.  They are also going in search of the Holy Grail, the cup from which Jesus drank at the Last Supper.  He gathers several knights--not too many, because it's hard for them when they all have to appear in the same scene.  But there is Sir Lancelot (John Cleese), Sir Galahad (Michael Palin), Sir Bedevere (Terry Jones), Sir Robin (Eric Idle), and Sir Not Appearing in This Film (William Palin).  They have adventures--Sir Galahad finds Castle Anthrax and its Grail-shaped beacon; Sir Lancelot slaughters pretty much an entire wedding party; Sir Robin bravely runs away.  There are musical numbers.  There is animation.  There is the fearsome rabbit.  There are the taunting Frenchmen.  There are, most shockingly of all for a Python film, female characters actually played by women.  There isn't much of a plot, and there basically isn't an ending.

I've said before that the Pythons are the only group I can think of who preferred their experience filming in Tunisia, and having read some of what went wrong on this one, I can understand why.  At least in Tunisia, they weren't wearing wet wool and staying in a hotel with an inadequate supply of running water.  Graham Chapman had the DTs.  John Cleese filmed one scene standing on a cliff where, if he fell on one side, the drop could have killed him.  If he fell on the other, "it could have maimed me."  It's true that Camelot was only a model, because the Scottish Department of the Environment refused them permission to film in any of its castles, which is most of the castles in Scotland, because the script was "incompatible with the[ir] history and fabric."  They were given this with two weeks' notice, so they had to use two privately owned castles over and over and just hope no one noticed.  I won't say everything that could go wrong did, but quite a lot went wrong, and less did in Tunisia on [i]Life of Brian[/i].

People forget, or else don't realize, that the only Python without an "Oxbridge" education is Terry Gilliam, the American.  (Who went to Occidental, not itself a bad school, even if it isn't in quite the same league.)  This means that they are versed in all sorts of things that make it onscreen in surprising ways.  A knight running from a rabbit is a common medieval symbol of cowardice, for example, and so Sir Robin runs from the rabbit in our film.  Of course the monks are chanting in proper Latin; as [i]Life of Brian[/i] would later show, the Pythons know their Latin.  But more specifically, they are singing ecclesiastical Latin, an excerpt from the rites for the dead.  Even having Frenchmen in England is probably a reference to things like the Battle of Hastings.  The story isn't quite as full of historical parody of [i]Life of Brian[/i], which was full of nuggets about first-century Palestine, but there's still enough to keep a history major amused.

I don't have as much of a problem with people who obsessively quote this movie.  After all, I've seen it, and the quotes aren't spoiling anything for me.  What I do have a problem with is people who quote the movie in place of being funny themselves.  Someone I knew when I was in grade school did "the Holy Hand Bouquet of Antioch" at her wedding, and that was funny.  Randomly quoting from this movie is less so.  The issue with Yvonne's wedding was the context.  She got a friend to read from an enormous book, and they went through the whole thing.  It wasn't as funny as it was during the movie, but it was funnier than someone who just quoted those lines for no good reason randomly during a conversation about something else.  It is true that "Pythonesque" is a real word in real dictionaries, though not the one my browser uses.  I've heard an argument that its very existence means that they failed at their humour, and I don't accept that, but I do believe being funny is more than just being a parrot, alive or dead.

PLOT:King Arthur and his Knights of the Round Table are sent by God to recover the Holy Grail. It is a simple story told in different adaptions over and over in various ways, but this way is the most memorable, with goofy twists and classic moments.

ACTING:The Monty Python troupe serves it up the best they can. Their brand of silly-yet-serious, sarcastic, and dumb acting works in every movie, even if the movie itself sucks.

SCORE:Typical, but meant to be that way. Fun songs, and a nice piano interlude near the end.

EFFECTS/ANIMATION:This had both. The animation is of the typical Monty Python brand, which works well, considering this IS a Monty Python film. Duh! The effects were really low-budget and bad looking, but I think they were meant to be that way, so I won't bash them too hard.

CAMERAWORK:FOr a Monty Python film, there is actually some very nice, nostalgic camerawork in here.

OTHER CONTENT:Why didn't I give this the full? You may ask. Well, the answer is that I find it to be over-ridiculous at times. I mean, I know it's supposed to be that way, but I just can't get into it. It doesn't interest me as it may some. I guess that's why they call it a cult movie. Also, I hated the ending a lot. I know it was supposed to give off the initial "That was it?" reaction, but like I said, I just can't get into it. On the bright side, it does have some of the most memorable quotes, such as "It's just a flesh wound!" and "I fart in your general direction!"

OVERALL,a great Monty Python movie with memorable version of a classic plot, greatly original acting, made-to-be typical score, made-to-be bad effects, greatly original animation, nostalgic camerawork, and memorable quotes. But there are times where I find it overly ridiculous that I just can't get into, not to mention the ending..

Nearly 40 years after its initial release, this surreal spoof of the King Arthur legend is a film that has aged superbly. This was the film that introduced me to Monty Python in the first place, and with its instant appeal - stoked by cleverly written humour, brilliant set-pieces, charismatic acting, and a whole host of memorable moments - it became my favourite comedy film of all time, and without hesitation, I can say this is simply the greatest film ever made. I could go on and on about my favourite moments from the film, but that would take forever. What I will comment on is how the Monty Python group has made incredibly effective use of their skills at playing numerous roles. They fit so well into the plethora of different roles that it's as though each role was a different pair of clothes. The film brandishes an excellently impersonated medieval style, blended with the group's signature style of surreal humour and farcical twists. It ultimately concludes in the total opposite of how every other re-telling of the King Arthur legend is told, with the knights being thwarted in the silliest possible way. The ending is only slightly jarring, but in such a way that it actually works well with the rest of the film. A well-aged classic, this is the kind of film that, sadly, can never be made again. After all, you can only make the greatest film of all-time once.

Before Holy Grail, the Pythons had not shown that long-form comedy was within their range. The longest sketches on their Flying Circus TV show, like "Scott of the Antarctic" or "The Piranha Brothers," ran at most ten or fifteen minutes. Terry Gilliam, unquestionably the sixth of the six main cast members, had filled some of the more outlandish bit parts in the show but was best known for creating its often-perverse animated sequences. Holy Grail changed all of that. The troupe's stock-in-trade, satirical setups that devolve almost instantly into absurdity, proved so adaptable to the feature-length format that Holy Grail became arguably their most widely-recognized and beloved work.  Most of the individual vignettes, like the Black Knight and the witch-weighing scene, derive from the medieval setting, but the cadence of the delivery and the flair for wordplay are distinctly Pythonian. The film was also the springboard for Terry Gilliam's surprisingly-successful directorial career, and is a good example of his ability to create an off-kilter, vaguely-creepy atmosphere.

Easily the best thing the Pythoners did on the big screen, and a perfect companion piece to Bresson's Lancelot du Lac.Where Bresson used the camera to deconstruct the Arthurian legends, the Pythons used surealism and scatological humor. Features one of the best pucnline I've heard in a Python film ("Well, you have to know these things when you're king, you know") and one of the strangest, funniest credit sequences in any film.

I wouldn't at all be surprised if Monty Python and the Holy Grail were the silliest comedy ever. The amount of stupendous incredulity it showcases at each and every turning point simply baffles and confounds reason to all new comedic heights. But then again, it would have lost all its effective charm were that NOT the case. I firmly feel quite reasonable in awarding this, in my personal measure, a full five stars, not only because it was funny and humorous, but also because of its gags, under-hand and not-so-apparent exposes of non-sequiturs, goofs and the like, which in the end proved to be more classic than all the rest of its humor. To be honest, this is definitely the silliest comedy I've ever seen. It's full of impossible anachronistic plot, filled with innuendos and parodies, and of course deadpan humor. But the plot-line held on strongly, with effective timing, choreography, plus quite an amount of parallel storytelling which really evoked my interest throughout. Without the likes of John Cleese, Graham Chapman, Eric Idle, and the rest of its cast and crew, all this would not have been possible at all. In the end, as with its ravishing beginning (with those "opening credits"), Monty Python and the Holy Grail is definitely one of the funniest films I've seen thus far. At any rate, it's surely the silliest.

This was the first "proper" feature film of the Monty Python group and, as always with their movies, became legendary for their fans! The story follows King Arthur and his knights on the quest and it was based on Arthurian Legend ... of course, when the story was directed by Jones and Gilliam, you'll expect that will not follow the legend entirely. Along with the rest of the Pythons, Jones and Gilliam performed several roles in the film, but it was Chapman who took the lead as King Arthur. It was nice that John Cleese returned to the group for the film, feeling that the group were once again breaking new ground. Holy Grail was filmed on location, in picturesque rural areas of Scotland, and the money for filming were raised in part with investments from rock groups such as Pink Floyd, Jethro Tull and Led Zeppelin...

The influence of this group of funny men is huge... amongst the more visible ones is the inclusion of terms either directly from, or derived from, Monty Python, into the lexicon of the English language. The most obvious of these is the term 'pythonesque', which has become a byword in surreal humour, and is included in standard dictionaries.
If you like the silly British humour - it is a must - if you're just a normal person, feel free to skip it!

For several years this movie was all I knew about Monty Python, and frankly it was enough.  The humor in this movie made it clear that whoever this Monty Python guy was, he obviously knows how to write jokes.  Later in life I discovered the other Python films and the TV series, but none of them measured up to the genius of this film.  I'm not sure why this movie is so much better in my estimation, but it is.  The Monty Python cast is superbly funny in this movie, of course.  I'm particularly fond of John Cleese, but all the guys are amazing here.

To be frank, it feels like this movie shouldn't work.  Similar to the TV shows this movie is essentially just a series of little skits that are loosely held together by an overarching story.  Yet each one of those short skits is hysterical genius.  I can't help laughing uncontrollably at most of it, even though it largely makes no sense whatsoever.  I'm not sure what it is that makes British humor like this work so well, but despite the inanity of the situations, it all just plays as wildly hilarious.  Even some of the more gory/bloody moments in this film have a surprising humor about them.

The negative of this movie is simply that this type of comedy is definitely an acquired taste.  If you weren't born with the gene that allows you to laugh when a knight who says "Ni" is startled by the word "it" then there's no possible way you will appreciate this film.  That's part of the drawback of British humor because people either get it, or they don't, and there are very few people in between.  Luckily I am blessed with the necessary sense of humor,and that means this is, in my opinion, one of the funniest comedies of all time.

The one and only.  This is THE essential farcical comedy all revolving around King Arthur and his knights, who are on a quest from God to seek the Holy Grail.  What can you say about this that hasn't already been said before?  Even if you've never seen it, you've surely been around people riffing it without your knowing.  This is the Monty Python troupe on the very top of their game, and there is a sick genius here that transcends budgetary constraints.  Every single scene is reference worthy and laugh out loud funny, and it is one of those comedies that just gets funnier every time you see it, which is damn hard to accomplish, because so much of comedy relies on the element of surprise.  From the knights who say ni to the black knight to the killer rabbit to the dissertation on African and European swallows, there's plenty here to keep you rolling around in your seat.  Every scene is not only memorable, it's iconic, and this is a cult classic for a reason.  It's the type of comedy that's timeless, and I don't see this ever fading away into obscurity.

Without a doubt, this is one of the most funniest movies I have ever seen in my life.  This isn't your ordinary comedy that contains repetitive jokes and humor that repeats the same drug and fart jokes from previous comedy flicks. This is comedy that is quite original and will definitely bring in some great laughs, if you don't mind the silly setting. I liked the fact of  how the Monty Python crew act silly and poked fun at the legendary myth of King Arthur and his quest for the Holy Grail. You have this epic journey that all of us have read or heard about and the crew did a tremendous job of just making a complete joke out of their travels. During their journey, the knights will go through various encounters that brings in a type of humor that is definitely unimaginable and original. The stuff the characters go through may look a little childish and silly, but how the crew played out these scenarios worked really well, making the film enjoyable and fun; just suspend your disbelief and enjoy the absolute foolishness brought by the crew. 

I'll probably go and say that the humor is smart because it doesn't present any downright crud and playing out scenarios hilariously to a point where you will have fun, even if you are not laughing out loud. The comedic timing was absolutely superb and presented many classical scenes that will make it hard to point out a favorite. None of the jokes were out of control or pushed the limits to cause controversy, what this film presented were original jokes that I wouldn't have imagined to be put onto screen. The film played out these comic book related scenarios and successfully pulling these course of events perfectly. I really found myself laughing constantly, even up to points where my stomach would hurt.

One thing that I really found unique was how the Python crew will portray as more than one character. There are no boundaries to what type of role they will play, either acting as a young/old man or woman, hero/villain, minor characters, etc. This is what I find unique and great about their films because it is definitely something you will never see and they pulled it off perfectly. You won't know what type of character they will play and they do a great job of acting as their roles. This film is definitely a recommendation to all, as you will have a great time watching this film, while laughing your guts out.

Perhaps what really interested me with this film however, is it's sense of place.  In the process of being totally ludicrous and arguably trying too hard to be funny, the picture has a grimy, dirty, cold look to it, exactly the look i would expect out of a tale about a bunch of medieval knights, it lend a great deal of authenticity to it's otherwise silly premise.  Also, when the film winks it's eye at you and decides to briefly play it straight, it's as good as any adventure drama available, but then you recall everyone is riding imagined horses as they thunder onward. funny stuff.

This movie is so beloved by its rabid cult followers that it makes it unenjoyable for the rest of us. THERE I SAID IT. Anglophiles are a serious problem in America, people with an uncomfortable love of the British who so rabidly eat up and defend everything the country has produced you feel like maybe you shouldn't like it so you don't have to be like them. Which is too bad, because I do like Monty Python, I REALLY do. Sketch Comedy has long been one of my favorite modes of entertainment but having spent hours watching Kids in the Hall and Whitest Kids U'Know they may not be my favorite, but I don't think there will ever be another Python. They remind me a lot of children's cartoons but more for the adult audience and can also be enjoyed by children as opposed to vice versa. The writing is certainly clever and most of the time adult but everything is handled so light heartedly and silly you find it hard finding reasons too not let them watch it. Not just the classics either, most episodes of Monty Python's Flying Circus are pretty hilarious from start to finish but as later sketch comedy groups have shown even the best of this genre are not necessarily good at making movies. Python were one of the first to give it the old college try though, filming the Holy Grail between seasons of the show mostly on location in Scotland. However it the film seemed doomed from the get go, with a low budget, dispute among the members and other things setting them back which begs the question is this film worth the worship so many give it? Let's take a look that is but a flesh wound.

The film is shot a lot like a series of skits with the same theme around the middle but we start things off with the set up which is that King Arthur (Graham Chapman, who was PISS Drunk during the making of this my God) is assembling his Knights of the Round Table, including Sir Lancelot (John Cleese who gets the best roles in this movie if you ask me), Sir Robin (Eric Idle who's supporting characters are a lot funnier but Sir Robin's cool), Sir Bedevere the Not So Wise (Terry Jones who is probably the most underrated of the group) and his squire Patsy (Gilliam who's...very weird as typical of him) to go fetch the Holy Grail as God has tasked him. Basically it's an exceedingly silly take on the classic King Arthur Legend and all the knights go their separate ways to find the grail so that the members of the troupe can cheaply play all of the characters in the film. Along the way they encounter classic trials and tribulations like the dreaded Knights who say Ni, Carol Cleveland's tits and a three headed knight who eats people among other things.

Alright first of all let me again say, the crazed, rabid fan base of this film RUIN it for the rest of us. The Knights who say NI were HILARIOUS the first time I saw them I was in stitches with every line masterfully delivered in that ridiculous voice by Michael Palin. I loved the exchange between Eric Idle's Dead Ringer and some man trying to dispose of their father the first time I saw that as well and understood why everyone else loved it so much. I found all of these classic scenes and gags funny. Until the fucking fans of this movie both insufferable people I know and my own actual friends quoted these fucking scenes ad infinitum at which point I wanted to create a time machine to make sure this never existed. I don't understand why this movie in particular people have to ruin SO much to the point it's become a pop culture joke it's not like the movie's perfect by any means. Some of the jokes are utterly pointless other than to satisfy their low budget like the coconut replacing horses not that, that's not charming in its own right. Jones and Gilliam co directed this film and you can see the two drastically different directors pulling it in two different directions. Gilliam has an eye for the absurd and crazy and handles many scenes as such sometimes at the expense of the joke, like the whole Castle Anthrax business. Jones is much less creative, but honestly much better suited for this type of film. Furthermore certain parts seem incredibly sophomoric and childish in all the wrong ways, causing the scenes to drag on and on much longer than they should like...The Castle Anthrax scene again which is easily the flimsiest "sketch" of the movie. And furthermore Graham Chapman is very good and funny in some scenes but as has now become common knowledge was a raging alcoholic when this was filmed and this shows in a NUMBER of different scenes, too many.

You shouldn't hold a movie's fan base against it, they can choose what type of people their film will appeal too but now how said people will act on this liking. But when a movie has as many flaws as this you probably like me really want too, if nothing else just to rub all the things it does wrong in their smarmy little faces. I think most nerds have a touch of anglophile to them and as such most nerds can admit that at some point at least they've liked this movie which may explain how bafflingly over the top people react to this. I liked this movie, this is a damn fine movie and one of the best comedies both of the 70s and all time. But guys, at the end of the day it's still the third best Python movie out of three. But of course it's the Pythons so the touch of excellence is still there and if you haven't watched this it's time to stomach all those lines you've heard too many times before and give it a try.

Will I give this movie the full rating? Ni!

PLOT:King Arthur and his Knights of the Round Table are sent by God to recover the Holy Grail. It is a simple story told in different adaptions over and over in various ways, but this way is the most memorable, with goofy twists and classic moments.

ACTING:The Monty Python troupe serves it up the best they can. Their brand of silly-yet-serious, sarcastic, and dumb acting works in every movie, even if the movie itself sucks.

SCORE:Typical, but meant to be that way. Fun songs, and a nice piano interlude near the end.

EFFECTS/ANIMATION:This had both. The animation is of the typical Monty Python brand, which works well, considering this IS a Monty Python film. Duh! The effects were really low-budget and bad looking, but I think they were meant to be that way, so I won't bash them too hard.

CAMERAWORK:FOr a Monty Python film, there is actually some very nice, nostalgic camerawork in here.

OTHER CONTENT:Why didn't I give this the full? You may ask. Well, the answer is that I find it to be over-ridiculous at times. I mean, I know it's supposed to be that way, but I just can't get into it. It doesn't interest me as it may some. I guess that's why they call it a cult movie. Also, I hated the ending a lot. I know it was supposed to give off the initial "That was it?" reaction, but like I said, I just can't get into it. On the bright side, it does have some of the most memorable quotes, such as "It's just a flesh wound!" and "I fart in your general direction!"

OVERALL,a great Monty Python movie with memorable version of a classic plot, greatly original acting, made-to-be typical score, made-to-be bad effects, greatly original animation, nostalgic camerawork, and memorable quotes. But there are times where I find it overly ridiculous that I just can't get into, not to mention the ending..

More than one person has confessed to me that they just don't 'get' Monty Python. Some of them have asked what it is they're overlooking, what the point is. I tell them that they aren't overlooking anything. The whole point of Monty Python is that there is no point. It's nonsensical, over-the-top, and you either get it or you don't. Or you do and you're highly offended. I confess that I don't get all of their routines, Confuse-A-Cat for example, but I find most of their material hilarious. And no-where are they funnier than in Holy Grail.
	Even if you've never seen the movie, or don't have any idea who or what Monty Python is, you already know parts of this movie. Things like the killer bunny, the knights who say Ni, and the Black Knight "Tis only a flesh wound!" have become part of popular culture. Who in the English speaking world hasn't heard of the Holy Hand Grenade of Antioch? Many people may not know where it came from, but they've heard of it. Same for the infamous cries of "Bring out your dead!"
 Practically all of the film's uproarious routines are widely known, and can be recited word for word by legions of fans. Every scene is just plain funny, and how could they not be, considering the people involved. John Cleese, Erik Idle, and the rest are simply master comedians. Their timing and delivery are perfect, and more importantly, they have some of the most brilliant, deranged imaginations anywhere. 
These guys come up with ideas unlike any that have been thought of before, like a three headed giant who argues with himself about tea and scones, or an order of knights dedicated to shrubberies and the saying of a fictional curse, or a giant cartoon beast that nearly kills the heroes before the animator suffers a fatal heart attack. Or they use deliberate anachronisms, like medieval peasants spouting socialist dogma, or King Arthur killing a noted historian who was recapping the last scene. Yeah, Monty Python breaks the fourth wall fairly often.
And they also come up with totally new ways of looking at a well known subject. Take the princess trapped in the castle, who must be rescued by a brave knight. Here they turn the situation on its head by substituting a whiny prince for the beautiful princess, and manage to skewer both sappy song-and-dance numbers and mindless violence while they're at it. Witch hunts are another familiar subject. We've all seen plenty of witch burnings in the movies, but this is the first time that the accused witch is tried using the latest "scientific methods." The logic displayed here is "more tortured than Pavarotti at a Tiny Tim concert" to quote Scott Adams, and it's absolutely side splitting.
Holy Grail was the epitome of randomness long before the term had been coined. It is a total farce, in which even the opening credits and the intermission are a joke. It's silly, it's inane, it's insane, it has plot holes you could drive a truck through, and it's one of my favorite comedies.

And I loved it, I don't think it is quite as good as Life of Brian, but it is definitely one of the better Monty Python comedies for sheer hilarity and fun. The story like Life of Brian isn't the strongest component but this is in no way a criticism and yes the special effects are cheesy but perhaps that was the intention. My only problem with the film was that the ending is a little flat, but that is a minor criticism compared to how much I loved this film. The script is irreverent and highly quotable, and the soundtrack is even funnier. As a comedy it is wonderfully inventive, that debunks the Dark Ages and legends of chivalry through King Arthur, The Black Knight, God and the "knights who say ni". Comedy highlights include the trial with Connie Booth's witch and the Holy Hand Grenade of Antioch sequence. Even the sets are quite well designed and authentic. And the acting is simply wonderful, John Cleese, Terry Jones(the encounter with Dennis's mother was hilarious), Graham Chapman, Terry Gilliam, Michael Palin and Eric Idle perfectly live up to their exceptional talents. Overall, a great comedy and a great film. 9.5/10 Bethany Cox

Everything, from Marxist rhetoric to scientific observations to religious doctrine, takes a beating. Most comedies saturate the audience with gags and jokes in the hope that one-third to one-half of the material might be funny. But, in The Holy Grail, there's hardly an attempt at humor that fails. rt_summary: A comedic send-up of the grim circumstances of the Middle Ages as told through the story of King Arthur and framed by a modern-day murder investigation. When the mythical king of the Britons leads his knights on a quest for the Holy Grail, they face a wide array of horrors, including a persistent Black Knight, a three-headed giant, a cadre of shrubbery-challenged knights, the perilous Castle Anthrax, a killer rabbit, a house of virgins, and a handful of rude Frenchmen.
meta_summary: The Monty Python team are at it again in their second movie. This time we follow King Arthur and his knights in their search for the Holy Grail. This isn't your average medieval knights and horses story - for a start, due to a shortage in the kingdom, all the horses have been replaced by servants clopping coconuts together!
